text: Domestic survey data and tables were prepared by Christopher H. Lindsay, statistical assistant, and the world production
label: BODY

text: table was prepared by Glenn J. Wallace, international data coordinator.
label: BODY

text: The mineral talc is a hydrous magnesium silicate.  A massive
label: BODY

text: talcose rock is called steatite, and an impure massive variety is
label: BODY

text: known as soapstone.  Talc is used commercially because of its
label: BODY

text: fragrance retention, luster, purity, softness, and whiteness.
label: BODY

text: Other commercially important properties of talc are its
label: BODY

text: chemical inertness, high dielectric strength, high thermal
label: BODY

text: conductivity, low electrical conductivity, and oil and grease
label: BODY

text: adsorption.  Major markets for talc are ceramics, paint, paper,
label: BODY

text: Pyrophyllite is a hydrous aluminum silicate with a structure
label: BODY

text: similar to talc.  Such properties as chemical inertness, high
label: BODY

text: dielectric strength, high melting point, and low electrical
label: BODY

text: conductivity make it useful for ceramic and refractory
label: BODY

text: In 1999, the U.S. Department of Defense authorized the
label: BODY

text: disposal of 907 metric tons (t) of block and lump talc from the
label: BODY

text: National Defense Stockpile, which is the entire uncommitted
label: BODY

text: inventory in that category; 2 t was sold.
label: BODY

text: Talc.—In 1999, 9 companies operating 13 mines in 6 States
label: BODY

text: produced soapstone, steatite, and talc.  All but one operation
label: BODY

text: were open pit mines.  The producers were, in decreasing order
label: BODY

text: of production, Luzenac America Inc., Barrett’s Minerals Inc.,
label: BODY

text: Dal Minerals Co., Gouverneur Talc Co., Milwhite Inc.,
label: BODY

text: Suzorite Mineral Products Inc. (Zemex Corp.), Unimin Texas
label: BODY

text: Co. L.P. (formerly United Clays Inc. of Texas), Steatite of
label: BODY

text: Southern Oregon, and NuTECH Minerals Inc.  Barrett’s
label: BODY

text: Minerals, Dal Minerals, Gouverneur Talc, and Luzenac
label: BODY

text: America were the largest domestic producers, accounting for
label: BODY

text: In 1999, U.S. mine production was 925,000 t valued at $26.1
label: BODY

text: million, compared with 971,000 t valued at $27.3 million in
label: BODY

text: 1998 (tables 1 and 2).  Production increased slightly in New
label: BODY

text: York; decreased in California, Montana, Texas, and Vermont;
label: BODY

text: and remained unchanged in Oregon.  Montana led all States in
label: BODY

text: the tonnage and value of talc produced, followed by Texas,
label: BODY

text: Vermont, New York, Oregon, and California.  Mines that
label: BODY

text: operated in Montana, New York, Texas, and Vermont
label: BODY

text: accounted for nearly all the domestic talc production.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: one mine in California, and Piedmont Minerals Co. and
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Talc.—Approximately 881,000 t of talc valued at $102
label: BODY

text: million was sold or used in 1999, an increase from 870,000 t
label: BODY

text: valued at $109 million in 1998.  Sales or use of talc increased
label: BODY

text: in Montana and Texas; decreased in California, New York, and
label: BODY

text: Vermont; and remained essentially unchanged in Oregon.  Of
label: BODY

text: the 881,000 t of talc sold or used, producers reported that
label: BODY

text: 771,000 t was sold for domestic use and approximately 110,000
label: BODY

text: Domestic markets included, in decreasing order of
label: BODY

text: paper, paint, plastics, roofing, cosmetics, rubber, insecticides,
label: BODY

text: and refractories (table 3).  Domestic sales of talc did not change
label: BODY

text: About 73,000 t of talc was reported under the “Other”
label: BODY

text: category by respondents in 1999.  Of this amount, 55,600 t was
label: BODY

text: used in animal feed additives, automobile body fillers, caulks,
label: BODY

text: joint compounds, paint and putties, sculpture media, tile
label: BODY

text: flooring, and vinyl sheet flooring.  The remainder of the
label: BODY

text: “Other” category (17,400 t) was used in applications that were
label: BODY

text: Most of the imported talc was not included in the domestic
label: BODY

text: end-use data listed in table 3.  More than 80% of the imported
label: BODY

text: talc was purchased by mineral brokers who do not participate in
label: BODY

text: the USGS canvass.  An estimate of the end-use breakdown
label: BODY

text: based on countries of origin, ports of entry, importing
label: BODY

text: companies, and regional end-use patterns is ceramics and
label: BODY

text: refractories, 15,000 t; cosmetics, 8,000 t; paint, 31,000 t; paper,
label: BODY

text: 12,000 t; plastics, 80,000 t; rubber, 9,000 t; and unknown,
label: BODY

text: decreased from that of 1998.  Pyrophyllite was used, in
label: BODY

text: decreasing order of consumption, in ceramics, refractories,
label: BODY

text: paint, plastics, insecticides, and rubber.  Sales increased for
label: BODY

text: paint and plastics applications and decreased for the others.
label: BODY

text: Ceramic and refractory uses accounted for 61% of domestic
label: BODY

text: Domestic consumption data for talc and pyrophyllite were
label: BODY

text: developed by the USGS from a voluntary survey of U.S. mills.
label: BODY

text: Survey forms were sent to 11 companies operating 16 mills in 8
label: BODY

text: States for talc and 3 companies operating 3 mills in 2 States for
label: BODY

text: pyrophyllite.  Approximately 87% of the talc data presented in
label: BODY

text: table 3 was reported by the companies; the remainder was
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: industry trends.  All the pyrophyllite producers responded to

text: Talc prices varied depending on the quality and the degree
label: BODY

text: and method of processing.  The unit value of crude talc was
label: BODY

text: estimated to be $28 per metric ton.  More than 80% of the
label: BODY

text: crude ore value included in table 1 was estimated because most
label: BODY

text: producers do not sell crude talc and could not provide a crude
label: BODY

text: ore value.  The average reported unit value of processed talc
label: BODY

text: was $116 per ton.  The average unit values of crude and
label: BODY

text: The average unit value for exports of unmilled talc was $114
label: BODY

text: per ton, and that of milled talc was $195 per ton.  The average
label: BODY

text: unit value for imports was $83 per ton for unground talc, $161
label: BODY

text: per ton for ground talc, and $932 per ton for cut or sawed talc.
label: BODY

text: Bidding for export licenses on 250,000 t of Chinese talc took
label: BODY

text: place in March 1999.  Licenses, in general, increased about $8
label: BODY

text: per ton to $20 per ton.  Industry experts believe that much of
label: BODY

text: the increase in licensing costs could be absorbed through cost
label: BODY

text: reductions by Chinese talc producers (Mineral PriceWatch,
label: BODY

text: Approximate prices for talc ranged from $83 to $371 per ton
label: BODY

text: (table 4; Industrial Minerals, 1999d).  Quoted prices should be
label: BODY

text: used only as a guideline because actual prices depend on the
label: BODY

text: terms of the contract between seller and buyer.
label: BODY

text: Talc exports increased slightly in tonnage, to 147,000 t, and
label: BODY

text: 5% in value, to $27.2 million.  Canada was the leading
label: BODY

text: importer of U.S. talc, followed by Mexico, Belgium, Japan,
label: BODY

text: Venezuela (7,220 t), and Taiwan (4,560 t) (table 5).  Since
label: BODY

text: 1990, data reported by domestic producers concerning exports
label: BODY

text: to Mexico gradually have diverged from the Bureau of the
label: BODY

text: Census data.  On the basis of industry data, exports to Mexico
label: BODY

text: are estimated to be more than three times those reported by the
label: BODY

text: Talc imports reported by the Bureau of the Census increased
label: BODY

text: by 26% in tonnage, to 208,000 t, and increased by 52% in
label: BODY

text: value, to $35.3 million.  Such a large tonnage increase probably
label: BODY

text: could not be absorbed by current talc markets and it is likely
label: BODY

text: that much was processed and stockpiled for future sales.  Cut
label: BODY

text: and sawed talc, which has a unit value of $932 per ton,
label: BODY

text: contributed disproportionately to the large increase in the
label: BODY

text: import value compared with import values for unmilled and
label: BODY

text: milled talc.  Canada, China, France, and Japan supplied 89% of
label: BODY

text: all talc imports (table 6).  Some of the talc imported from Japan
label: BODY

text: was likely to have been transshipments from other Southeast
label: BODY

text: Approximately 50% (103,000 t) of talc imported into the
label: BODY

text: United States came through the port district of New Orleans,
label: BODY

text: LA, almost all unmilled.  Of this amount, 6,700 t was imported
label: BODY

text: from Australia; 86,700 t from China; 68 t from France; 8,990 t
label: BODY

text: from Hong Kong; and 244 t from Italy.  The second leading
label: BODY

text: port district was Detroit, MI, with 25,400 t (principally from
label: BODY

text: Canada); followed by Boston, MA, with 21,000 t (principally
label: BODY

text: from France); and Buffalo, NY, with 12,400 t (principally from
label: BODY

text: Canada).  The remaining imports were scattered among the
label: BODY

text: China remained the world’s leading producer of talc,
label: BODY

text: followed by the United States, Brazil, India, Finland, and
label: BODY

text: France.  The Republic of Korea was the largest producer of
label: BODY

text: pyrophyllite, followed by Japan and Brazil.  China, Japan, the
label: BODY

text: Republic of Korea, and the United States produced 69% of the

text: Australia.—WMC Resources Ltd. announced plans to build
label: BODY

text: an $11 million mill with a capacity of 35,000 to 40,000 metric
label: BODY

text: tons per year (t/yr) at either its Three Springs or Kwinana site.
label: BODY

text: The mill will permit WMC to use talc from its Three Springs
label: BODY

text: mine for higher value applications.  The paper and paint
label: BODY

text: markets in Australia and Southeast Asia are being served by the
label: BODY

text: Canada.—Highwood Resources Ltd. acquired a talc mine
label: BODY

text: and mill from Canada Talc Ltd.  The mine and mill are located
label: BODY

text: in Madoc, Ontario.  Highwood Resources is beginning
label: BODY

text: underground development at the mine to improve access to
label: BODY

text: higher grade ore.  The company also is upgrading the mill
label: BODY

text: Trinity Resources and Energy Ltd. began preparing its
label: BODY

text: pyrophyllite mine and mill, which have been idle since 1995,
label: BODY

text: for operation.  In 1998, the company acquired the mine and
label: BODY

text: mill, located in Newfoundland, from Armstrong World
label: BODY

text: Industries Canada Ltd.  The purchase included the mine, mill,
label: BODY

text: 1 million tons of reserves, and ceramic- and mixed-grade
label: BODY

text: stocks.  The company expects to be fully operational in 2000
label: BODY

text: and intends to diversify from ceramics into pigment and filler
label: BODY

text: markets, such as paint, plastic, and roofing (North American
label: BODY

text: Italy.—Luzenac Val Chisone SpA opened an underground
label: BODY

text: mine in Rodoretto.  The deposit contains high-purity, white,
label: BODY

text: macrocrystalline ore.  Luzenac anticipates that production will
label: BODY

text: be 60,000 t/yr.  The talc will be sold for polymer, cosmetic,
label: BODY

text: Sierra Talc de Mexico, SA de CV.  Sierra Talc is a toll
label: BODY

text: grinding operation with an average output of 40,000 t/yr.  It has
label: BODY

text: mines in Guerrero and Puebla and mills in Monterrey and
label: BODY

text: Mexico City.  The company mines about 10% of its feed
label: BODY

text: material with the remainder obtained from other producers
label: BODY

text: Markets for talc should be stable and even slightly increasing
label: BODY

text: for the next few years.  Major markets for talc, such as
label: BODY

text: ceramics, paint, paper, and plastics, are projected to grow
label: BODY

text: slowly through 2003 as a result of the strong U.S. economy.
label: BODY

text: The plastics market should continue to offer the greatest growth
label: BODY

text: potential for talc, and imports will play a larger role in the U.S.
label: BODY

text: talc market.  No major changes are anticipated in pyrophyllite
label: BODY

text: markets, and consumption probably will not change
label: BODY

text: significantly for the next few years.
label: BODY
